https://berdandy.com/.body:
Berdandy's Obsessions
This site is dedicated to my various obsessions, hobbies and work. I make all of this stuff.

https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-2/.body:
I decided to change the assembly order slightly. And accordingly, the plan.

I realized it would be easier to cut the cover to shape before attaching the internal pocket, so I started with that.
The current plan is:

Cut cover to shape, including snap loop
Cut a "reversed" cover pocket to accommodate a passport. A strong secondary use for this case is a passport holder.
Cut a pen holder to sit in snap loop (or spine?)
Assemble with temporary tape
Finish raw leather grips (cover and pocket material is already-finished leather)
Finish all interior edges
Assemble with grips and cover pocket and final trim
Finish exterior edges
Attach snap closure

All good plans don't survive implementation, so we'll see what happens.
https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-2/.description: Custom wet-formed case for a Kobo eBook, continued
https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-2/.title: Kobo eBook Case: The Plan

https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-3/.body:
I was motivated, so spent most of my Saturday doing the case manufacturing and assembly.

I began with a mock assembly with painter's tape
 

Next, I added the inside cover. I had cut out a port for a passport cover, traced around a popsicle
stick template. As the inside cover needed to accommodate the cover of the passport, I only want to
glue around the outside edge, not the full surface.
 

 

Next, I glued down the eBook grips, and once that had set, used an edger and stitching chisels to
form the stitching holes.
 

Then I cut and stitched the inset cover, as well as the grips. I also reinforced one side of the
passport slot.
I also cut a port on the back to allow access to the power button on the back of the
Kobo. I probably should have done that before I glued on the grips. Whoops.
 

As a final addition, I added a pen loop to the snap closure, reinforced the closure, and added the
snap.
 

However, when I had it all put together with the pen, there wasn't quite enough space to actually
have the pen in the loop and still snap it shut. I may add a second pen loop to the spine between
the passport and eBook.
Alternately, I'll remake the closure and give the pen more space. Drawbacks there is that the closure
wouldn't be seamless, but I could make it decorative.
Or both. It might be better to remove the almost-useless pen loop. I'll give it some thought...
https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-3/.title: Kobo eBook Case: Weekend Assembly Blitz

https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-4/.body:
After some reflection, the best course of action was to indeed remove the pen loop and put a new
one in the spine area.

First, I removed the ineffective pen loop: a simple slice through the top layer. The loop itself is a soft
leather, so I had to take care to not cut too far into the case itself.
 

I cut and glued the new pen loop in place. First, I glued one side...
 

Then prepped the loop closure by sanding off the slick grain side so the leather cement would better adhere.
 

Next, I marked the stitch line, punched the stitching holes with diamond chisels, and stitched the line
tight enough to hold the pen securely.

	 

	 

	 


Finally, burnishing the edges adds a bit of literal polish to the case. I already did the edge
beveling earlier.
 

And the final result, including a cover detail that was a last minute addition to hide the passport
slot reinforcement stitches.
https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-case-4/.title: Kobo eBook Case: Final Assembly

https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-wetformi.body:
My wife and I both got Kobo eBooks for ourselves, but she was unhappy with the stock case options. When I got into
leatherworking, I offered to make her a custom one once I had figured out how to not make terrible things.
There are a few options I explored:

Slipcover. Decided against, because it's not a permanent case.
Corner-grips. Decided aginst, because one corner would block the charging port.
Velcro-mount for a floating effect. Decided against, aesthetic reasons.
Wet-formed grips. This seems the most workable option.


After some digging, I finally found a random photo of someone who had done a similar thing, so I was confident
I wasn't completely off the mark. I wet-formed top-and-bottom "grips" for a test, and rough-cut material for a cover.
 

I can picture it now.

The remaining plan is:

Cut a "reversed" cover pocket to accommodate a passport. A strong secondary use for this case is a passport holder.
Cut a pen holder to sit in snap loop (or spine?)
Assemble with temporary tape
Cut cover to shape, including snap loop
Finish raw leather grips (cover and pocket material is already-finished leather)
Finish all interior edges
Assemble with grips and cover pocket and final trim
Finish exterior edges
Attach snap closure
https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-wetformi.description: Custom wet-formed case for a Kobo eBook
https://berdandy.com/blog/ebook-wetformi.title: Kobo eBook Case: Ideas/Preliminary

https://berdandy.com/blog/goldsmithing/.body:
When I decided to get married, I wanted something unique and personal for an
engagement ring. With the audacity of curiosity, I wandered into a local goldsmith's
shop with the intention of asking for some advice on how to explore making the engagement ring
myself.
Serendipity was with me that day, because it turned out that Jason had previously taught workshops,
but hadn't in several years. He was open to doing some custom lessons about lost-wax casting.
Fast-forward several months, a few dozen lunchtime lessons later, and I had created an
engagement ring in my own custom claddagh design
 
... and two wedding bands with line work that evokes a similar feeling:
https://berdandy.com/blog/goldsmithing/.title: Metalwork for a Wedding

https://berdandy.com/blog/hobbiesofhobbi.body:
It's hobbies, all the way down...
I make games professionally, and most of my hobbies are creative endeavours. And even some of my hobbies
have progressed into semi-professional status.
To some degree, I guess my true hobby is collecting hobbies. And then with enough time, they turn into
skills and careers.
The goal for this site is to have a home on the internet that can unify all this stuff in a single location, instead of going to This Place for music works, That Place for tabletop design works, The Other Place for video game works, The Fourth Place for physical crafting works, and so on and so on.
It's likely to be a little chaotic, but with a throughline of creativity.
Enjoy.
https://berdandy.com/blog/hobbiesofhobbi.title: Hobbies of hobbies

https://berdandy.com/blog/shopspace/.body:
I'm increasingly feeling limited by my need to unpack and repack my leatherworking tools and materials when I
somehow excavate some time and energy from my life -- and the competition for the dining room table is fierce.
As a result, I'm staking out some space in the basement for a multipurpose workspace.
The Plan


Reorganize existing woodworking tools

Move some tools to open up cluttered workbench for heavy stuff (hammering, stitching chisels, etc)

Get/build a second workbench for wet stuff (dying, painting, etc)

Bins & storage for leatherworking scraps and consumables

Make large material storage (rolled in cardboard concrete forms)

Bonus Ideas


Move guest room TV/speakers to shop

Small photography area using unused basement furniture

Getting there...
https://berdandy.com/blog/shopspace/.title: Leatherworking Shop Space

https://berdandy.com/blog/spring-music/.body:
I was rewatching Cowboy Bebop recently after unearthing old DVD collections, and evidently got inspired. As a
result, I made a very jazz-fusion-y track in honour of Jet, one of the main characters.

Today Berdandy was featured on a indie/fediverse-focused show, the NHAM Mixtapes. It's one of my older tracks,
Souls Beat Slow.

You can listen to the whole show at audiointerface.org, and I definitely recommend it. There's some good stuff in there.
https://berdandy.com/blog/spring-music/.title: Old Anime and New Music

https://berdandy.com/blog/wristcuff-map/.body:
I wanted to make a leather wrist cuff, inspired by some old Dungeons & Dragons style dungeon-crawl maps.

It's not your typical floral tooling design.
https://berdandy.com/blog/wristcuff-map/.title: Not That Kind of Dungeon
